{"step_by_step_thinking": "Thiazides are a type of diuretic that work by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron in the kidneys. This leads to an increase in sodium excretion (natriuresis). Increased sodium in the urine typically pulls water along with it, leading to increased urine output. Thiazides also increase the excretion of potassium (kaliuresis). However, thiazides decrease the excretion of calcium (hypocalciuria) by increasing calcium reabsorption in the distal tubule.
